facts.text: Club de Foot Montréal, originally founded as the Montreal Impact in 1992, began playing in Major League Soccer (MLS) in what year?
In what year did the Montreal Impact rebrand to Club de Foot Montréal?
How many times has CF Montréal (including its time as Montreal Impact) won the Voyageurs Cup?
11 times
In what year did Montreal Impact become the first Canadian club to advance to the final of the CONCACAF Champions League?
What was the Montreal Impact's first championship victory year in professional soccer?
What year did Saputo Stadium, the home of CF Montréal, open?
Who managed CF Montréal as of the last update?
Marco Donadel
In what year did the Montreal Impact win their first USL playoff championship?
The Impact won the first seven editions of the Voyageurs Cup from 2002 to 2007.
Since 2008, the Voyageurs Cup has been awarded to the winner of the Canadian Championship.
The Impact won the first edition of the Canadian Championship in 2008.
The Impact were defeated 5-4 on aggregate by Santos Laguna in the quarterfinals of the inaugural CONCACAF Champions League.
The Impact joined the USSF Division 2 Professional League for one season in 2010, finishing third in the NASL Conference.
The Impact led the league in average attendance in 2010 with 12,608 spectators per match.
Montreal was announced as the nineteenth club in Major League Soccer on May 7, 2010, set to begin play for the 2012 season.
The Montreal Impact announced a five-year agreement with the Bank of Montreal as their lead and jersey sponsor in MLS on June 14, 2011.
Jesse Marsch became the head coach of the Montreal Impact in August 2011.
The Montreal Impact signed Nelson Rivas, their first player for their inaugural MLS season, in October 2011.
The Montreal Impact played their inaugural MLS game on March 10, 2012, against Vancouver Whitecaps FC, resulting in a 2–0 loss.
The Montreal Impact set a new attendance record for professional soccer in Canada with 60,860 spectators during a game against the Los Angeles Galaxy on May 12, 2012.
Marco Di Vaio was signed as the Montreal Impact's first ever MLS Designated Player on May 24, 2012.
The Montreal Impact won their first major trophy since joining MLS, the 2013 Canadian Championship, on May 29, 2013.
The Montreal Impact earned their first-ever MLS playoff berth in the 2013 season.
Marco Schällibaum was named head coach of the Montreal Impact on January 7, 2013.
The Montreal Impact won the 2013 Walt Disney World Pro Soccer Classic on February 23, 2013.
Frank Klopas replaced Marco Schällibaum as the head coach of the Montreal Impact on December 18, 2013.
The Montreal Impact became repeat Voyageurs Cup champions by defeating Toronto FC in the 2014 Canadian Championship final on June 4, 2014.
The Montreal Impact finished last in the 2014 MLS season with a record of 6–18–10.

The Montreal Impact became the first Canadian club to win a two-legged series against a Mexican opponent when they defeated Pachuca in the quarterfinals of the CONCACAF Champions League on away goals (3-3 aggregate) in 2015.
Cameron Porter scored his first professional goal in stoppage time of the second leg against Pachuca, which was also his only goal for the Montreal Impact.
The Montreal Impact advanced to the CONCACAF Champions League finals for the first time in 2015, becoming the first Canadian club and only the second MLS club to do so.
The Montreal Impact faced Club América in the CONCACAF Champions League finals in 2015, with the first leg ending in a 1–1 draw at the Azteca Stadium in Mexico City.
Didier Drogba, formerly of Chelsea, joined the Montreal Impact mid-season in 2015.
Frank Klopas was fired as head coach of the Montreal Impact on August 29, 2015, and was replaced on an interim basis by former Impact player Mauro Biello, who was later hired permanently.
Rémi Garde, formerly of Aston Villa, succeeded Biello as the head coach of CF Montréal in October 2017.
Wilmer Cabrera replaced Rémi Garde as the interim head coach of CF Montréal in August 2019.
CF Montréal won the 2019 Canadian Championship by defeating Toronto FC in the finals under Wilmer Cabrera's interim leadership.
Thierry Henry signed a two-year deal to coach CF Montréal in November 2019.
CF Montréal made the MLS playoffs in Thierry Henry's first season as head coach but were eliminated by the New England Revolution in the first round.
CF Montréal's Champions League campaign during Thierry Henry's tenure ended in the quarter-finals with an away goals elimination by C.D. Olimpia.
Thierry Henry resigned as head coach of CF Montréal in February 2021, citing family reasons related to the pandemic.
Wilfried Nancy was named CF Montréal's head coach in May 2021 after an impressive start as interim head coach.
CF Montréal finished the 2022 MLS season in second place in the Eastern Conference and third place overall, the club's highest finish since joining MLS in 2012.
CF Montréal set a new MLS record for most road wins in a single season (11) and most consecutive road wins (7) in 2022.
CF Montréal were eliminated from the 2022 MLS playoffs in the Eastern Conference Semifinals by New York City FC.
Wilfried Nancy left CF Montréal to sign with Columbus Crew in December 2022 and was replaced by former D.C. United head coach Hernán Losada.

On June 27, 2023, CF Montréal manager Hernán Losada started six Québecois players in a match against the New England Revolution, the highest number of locally-based players in the starting XI since joining MLS.
The official logo for CF Montréal was revealed on August 6, 2011, during a match between the NASL Montreal Impact team and the NSC Minnesota Stars.
The previous logo of Montreal Impact featured a stylized fleur-de-lis and four silver stars, representing the four founding communities of Montreal.
The team's motto inscribed at the top of the shield before rebranding was "Tous Pour Gagner," which translates to "all for victory."
In 2020, Montreal Impact unveiled a new slogan, "Passion. Fierté. Authenticité." translating to "Passion. Pride. Authenticity."
In January 2021, the club rebranded to Club de Foot Montréal (CF Montreal) and introduced new official colours: "Impact Black", "Ice Grey", and "Sacré Bleu".
The new badge introduced in 2021 for CF Montreal featured four letter M's and eight arrows pointing to its centre, resembling a stylized snowflake.
The rebranding of Montreal Impact to CF Montreal in 2021 was poorly received by the club's main supporter group, the Ultras, leading to a protest in front of Saputo Stadium.

In May 2022, CF Montreal announced another badge change to take effect for the 2023 season, returning to the club's traditional colours with blue being predominant and featuring a stylized fleur-de-lis.
"Ultras Montréal", also known as "UM02", was founded in 2002 and was CF Montréal's largest and oldest supporters group with the motto "Toujours fidèles" translating to "Forever faithful".
In September 2021, CF Montréal management announced the banning of certain supporter groups, including the Ultras Montréal, following a feud that escalated due to the rebranding of the club.
"127 Montréal" was formed in which year? **2011**
The crest of "127 Montréal" features which bird, also the official bird of the Province of Québec? **Snowy Owl (Nyctea scandiaca)**
"1642 MTL" was established in what year? **2015**
The "North Star" bell was inaugurated on what date? **October 25, 2015**
Who inaugurated the "North Star" bell? **Montreal mayor Denis Coderre**
The "North Star" bell weighs how much? **1,576 pounds (715 kg)**
Which supporters group is the owner and caretaker of the North Star bell? **1642 MTL**
The official mascot of the club mentioned is named what? **Tac-Tik the dog**
On what date did the club announce the reopening of section 132 to supporter groups? **September 6, 2022**
Which group confirmed they would not be part of the "Collectif Impact Montréal"? **Ultras Montréal**
Montréal is nicknamed "The City of a Hundred Steeples" due to what? **The many church steeples that dominated the city's skyline**
CF Montréal's biggest rival is Toronto FC, known for the rivalry called the Canadian Classique or the 401 Derby.
The 2016 MLS Eastern conference finals between CF Montréal and Toronto FC is considered arguably MLS' greatest playoff series.
The first leg of the 2016 MLS Eastern conference finals at Stade Olympique in Montréal holds the record for the largest attendance for a match featuring two Canadian soccer teams, with 61,004 fans.
CF Montréal defeated Vancouver Whitecaps FC 3–1 in Montréal (6–3 on aggregate) to win the USL-1 league championship on October 17, 2009.
CF Montréal Academy was established in 2010.
The Ottawa Fury FC entered into an affiliation agreement with CF Montréal on December 9, 2016, which ended when Ottawa Fury was dissolved on November 8, 2019.
Saputo Stadium, CF Montréal's home stadium, has a capacity of 20,801 and was expanded with the anticipation of the club's move to MLS.
The expansion of Saputo Stadium was delayed, leading to the use of Olympic Stadium for CF Montréal's first six home dates in their inaugural 2012 MLS season.
CF Montréal's first MLS game at Saputo Stadium was played on June 16, 2012, resulting in a 4–1 win over Seattle.
Olympic Stadium in Montreal, also used by CF Montréal for special events, has a capacity of 61,004.
As of the 2023 season, all CF Montreal matches are available on MLS Season Pass on Apple TV with commentary options in which languages?
A) French, English, and Spanish
Until 2022, which network served as the regional rightsholder for CF Montreal matches?
A) TVA Sports
From 2015 through 2020, which radio station served as the French-language radio flagship for CF Montreal?
A) CHMP 98.5 FM
In 2021, which radio station became the new French-language radio flagship for CF Montreal?
A) CKLX 91.9 Sports
Which radio station serves as the English-language radio flagship for CF Montreal?
A) CKGM TSN 690 Montreal
Who is the owner of CF Montreal?
A) Joey Saputo
Who serves as the Interim Head Coach for CF Montreal?
A) Marco Donadel
In which year did CF Montreal win their first Canadian Championship?
How many times has CF Montreal won the Canadian Championship as of 2023?
In which year was CF Montreal the runner-up in the CONCACAF Champions Cup?
The Giuseppe Saputo Trophy is awarded to CF Montréal's Most Valuable Player.
CF Montréal's Golden Boot is given to the team's leading goalscorer, counting only MLS regular season goals.
The Defensive Player of the Year award at CF Montréal is given to the club's best defender.
The Jason Di Tullio Trophy is awarded to the player who best embodied the spirit of "La Grinta" throughout the MLS season.
CF Montréal was founded as an MLS franchise in 2010, originally established in 1992 as Montréal Impact.
Montreal was named as the 19th MLS city on May 7, 2010.
Montreal Impact's first soccer title came in 1994.
Montreal Impact became part of a revamped league on November 11, 2004.
A new soccer stadium for Montreal Impact received charitable contributions for its kickoff, as reported on May 5, 2005.
The Canadian Championship trophy, awarded to Canada's best soccer team, was fan-created, a fact highlighted on August 11, 2015.
Montreal Impact played their first MLS season opener against Vancouver Whitecaps on March 10, 2012.
Montreal Impact played to a 1–1 draw with Chicago Fire in their home debut before a massive crowd, as reported on March 17, 2012.
Montreal Impact tied LA Galaxy 1–1 in front of 60,860 spectators at Olympic Stadium, a match reported on December 5, 2012.
The Montreal Impact Academy was known as the Trois-Rivières Attak in the CSL from 2007 to 2009.
FC Montreal played in the USL from 2015 to 2016.
CF Montréal U23 has been playing in the L1Q since 2022.
CF Montréal won the Voyageurs Cup in 2008, 2013, 2014, 2019, and 2021.
The head coach position at CF Montréal has seen a series of changes with Thierry Henry serving from 2019 to 2021 and Wilfried Nancy from 2021 to 2023.
The "Miracle in Montreal" event took place in 2009.
Tampa Bay Mutiny, Miami Fusion, and Chivas USA are defunct MLS teams, with Chivas USA ceasing operations in 2014.
The Vancouver Whitecaps FC won the Canadian Championship in consecutive years, 2022 and 2023.
In MLS regular season matches between Montreal and Toronto from 2012 onwards, the teams have each won 13 times out of 31 matches.
Sebastian Breza, a goalkeeper from Canada, is player number 1 for CF Montréal.
Wilfried Nancy had the highest win percentage (46.84%) among the listed coaches of the club.
Romell Quioto was the top goalscorer for the club in both the 2020 and 2022 MLS seasons, with 10 and 15 goals respectively.
The club achieved its highest MLS regular season points total (65 points) in the 2022 season.
Thierry Henry served as the club's coach from November 14, 2019, to February 25, 2021.
The club participated in the CONCACAF Champions League in 2020, reaching the quarterfinals.
In the 2023 MLS season, Chinonso Offor was the club's top goalscorer with 5 goals.
The club's record against FAS in international competitions is 2 wins, 0 draws, and 0 losses, with a goal difference of +2.
Laurent Courtois had the lowest win percentage (26.67%) among the listed coaches of the club.
The club finished in 2nd place in the MLS regular season conference standings in 2022.
Marco Donadel had the lowest points per game (0.82) among the listed coaches of the club.
In 2015, during the Champions League, Montreal advanced against Pachuca with an aggregate score of 3-3 thanks to the away goals rule after drawing 1-1 in Montreal in front of 38,104 spectators.
In the 2020 Champions League, Montreal advanced past Saprissa with an aggregate score of 2-2, also thanks to the away goals rule, after a 0-0 draw in Montreal attended by 21,505 fans.
In 2022, Montreal won against Santos Laguna in the Champions League with an aggregate score of 3-1, after winning 3-0 in Montreal in front of 13,343 spectators.
In the 2023 Leagues Cup, Montreal defeated UNAM in a match that ended 2-2, winning 6-4 on penalties, with an attendance of 19,619.
Samuel Piette is the player with the most appearances for CF Montreal, having played 203 times since 2017.
Ignacio Piatti is both the top goal scorer and assist provider for CF Montreal, with 66 goals and 35 assists from 2014 to 2019.
Didier Drogba scored 21 goals for CF Montreal, making him the fourth highest goal scorer for the club, despite only playing from 2015 to 2016.
CF Montreal is ranked 27th in points among the teams listed, with a total of 1,174 points.
Evan Bush holds the record for the most appearances (176) and most clean sheets (40) by a goalkeeper for his club between 2012 and 2020.
Ignacio Piatti won the club's Player of the Year award four times consecutively from 2015 to 2018.
Marco Di Vaio scored the highest number of goals in a single season (20) for his club in 2013.
Romell Quioto was named the club's Player of the Year in both 2020 and 2022.
Mathieu Choinière was the club's Player of the Year in 2023.
Samuel Piette was named the club's Player of the Year in 2024.
Patrice Bernier was the first player to win the club's Player of the Year award in 2012.
Laurent Ciman was named the club's Defensive Player of the Year in 2015.
Didier Drogba scored 11 goals in the 2015 season for his club.
Jonathan Sirois was named the club's Defensive Player of the Year in 2023.
Patrice Bernier served as the club captain from 2014 to 2017.
Victor Wanyama and Kamal Miller both served as the club captains during the 2021–2022 period.
